ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
CHILDCARE SUBSIDY

(Review)


    1. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for Community Development when the Government will review its childcare subsidy again so as to help the lower-income group, to encourage more women to return to the workforce and to help working parents balance between work and family.

    The Minister for Community Development (Mr Abdullah Tarmugi): Mr Speaker, Sir, the provision of child care subsidies is

Column: 1276

precisely to help women to return to the workforce. The subsidy is given across the board to all Singaporean mothers in the workforce. Special help is given to low-income families who receive additional financial subsidies from the Centre-based Financial Assistance for Child Care Scheme.

    The subsidies are reviewed regularly and the last one we carried out was in April 1995. My Ministry is carrying out a study on how to provide more child care places to meet the demand and also to allow mothers more choices. We also want to ensure that child care is affordable to families, especially those with low-income. The subsidies will be reviewed as well. The study should be completed by the middle of this year.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai (Nominated Member ): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister what steps is the MCD taking to attract more mothers to join the workforce. I know it is the responsibility of Ministry of Labour.

    Mr Abdullah Tarmugi: Sir, as rightly pointed out by the Member, I think that Question should rightly be directed to the Ministry of Labour.

    Head R (cont.) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [13th March, 1998],

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head R of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Mr Chew Heng Ching].

    Question again proposed.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai: Sir, when I was cut off last Friday, I was speaking on TV programmes. It is important that TV programmes, especially the News that is telecast in Singapore, and as pointed out by the Minister last year in the Budget debate, should focus on the Singapore viewpoint. It is very important because

Column: 1277

sometimes I wonder what has a bus accident or small human story in America got to do. In fact, if there were other human stories of what is happening in Asia they would be much more relevant. So I would urge the News editors to focus and give a Singapore viewpoint whenever news is reported. There may be some human angle, I can agree. But to report on small incidents of road blocks, or things like that, I do not think it serves any purpose.

    May I now move to the question of Indian programmes, Sir. The Indian News programme is hampered because it has to depend on the other sections and it does not cover news on the Indian community as widely as it should. Also, there is a tendency for the Indian news programmes to focus on matters happening in India. I do not deny that India is an important country but to focus unduly on affairs in India, I think it is not good for Singapore, and I would urge that we should take a focused viewpoint. The Indian PAC has pointed this out. But I want to share my views with this House that we should try to portray India's problems in India's setting and not India's problems in Singapore setting.

    I think it would be good to have more journalists in this section. I know there are budget constraints. But I would ask the Minister to urge his colleague, the Finance Minister, to be a little more generous because I know the Indian programmes are not self-financing. But it is an important sector of the community and it should get its coverage, not only the Indian programmes but the other community and national programmes in the Indian channel.

    The other point is the question of timing. I know the timing has improved. The Minister may say that we are asking too much. But I think it would benefit half of the Indian community, especially the younger listeners and viewers, if the News programme could be shifted after 8.30 pm. The second point, Sir, is that we do not have a current affairs programme in the Indian segment. It is important to

Column: 1278

know what is happening around us in Singapore and we should have such a programme either twice a month or, if not, at least once a month. The programme could be for half an hour to one hour where the Indian viewers could have the opportunity to see the problems facing Singapore. For this, I think we should have funding. Again, I would urge the Minister to reconsider this.

    Sir, I must applaud TCS for the improvement in its quality of programmes. I think it would be hypocrisy not to admit that the standards have gone up. But I am asking the Minister to urge his officers to do something that we can be proud of our TV and radio programmes, especially when they compare with the news media. If you look at the Straits Times, it has got such a wide coverage, in particular From the Gallery. If we could have the same coverage for TV programmes, I think Singapore as a whole would benefit.

    Mr Seng Han Thong (Ang Mo Kio)(In Mandarin): Sir, the television programmes produced by TCS have become part and parcel of the Singapore culture, and the current affairs programmes and dramas produced by Channel 8 have also become part of the social life in the Chinese community in Singapore.

    1997 is an eventful year for Singapore. First, we were affected by the haze. Then there was this tension between Singapore and Malaysia, followed by the financial turmoil and the SilkAir tragedy. The current affairs programmes from Channel 8 such as Tuesday Report, Focus and Money Week gave extensive coverage and analysis of all these events for the benefit of Singaporeans who are concerned with the society and the fate of their compatriots. The efforts and prompt reports by the Current Affairs Section of TCS are indeed highly commendable.

    Not long ago, TCS telecast a serial known as Taxi Driver, which was well received by the audience in general, and the taxi drivers themselves in particular. They feel that this kind of drama truly reflects our society and the transport workers in our society. It shows not only

Column: 1279

their life but also their hardship. It would also promote better understanding between the taxi drivers and their commuters, as well as improve the image of taxi drivers. On behalf of the taxi drivers, I would like to record their appreciation to the producers of this serial.

    The Programme Advisory Committee in its report released recently, pointed out that among TCS's top 10 serials last year, two were considered to be undesirable, not suitable for children. One of them is the Choice Partner which conveys undesirable ideas and the other is Rising Expectations which has a very complicated plot, involving prostitution, rape and other very illicit relationship between men and women.

    The report commended the good social values depicted in The Price of Peace and Guest People.

    Sir, one related problem is that the viewership of Channel 8 drama serials has generally dropped. In the past, they used to command a viewership of more than 700,000, but now it has dropped to around 600,000. When we are producing television drama serials, no doubt we have to consider viewership, but with so many channels now available, a viewership of 600,000 can be considered not too bad. If we want to cater for the viewership and the revenue from the commercials, and add in plots which are undesirable and depict bad social values, then it is not good. I think we should not be too surprised by a drop in viewership because there are now so many channels available to the viewers. Viewership is spread out and thinned out. What TCS should do is to produce more programmes like The Price of Peace and Guest People to attract more viewers.

    In the last few days, we have been discussing the question of bond-breakers of our scholarship holders in this Parliament. This involves the basic value of trust. TCS may consider gathering more materials on this matter and produce a programme on scholarships, bond-breakers, and so on. Perhaps, the Minister may call upon TCS to consider producing

Column: 1280

a programme based on scholarship bond-breakers. If we have realistic programmes like this, it has a good chance of securing high viewership.

    Mr Choo Wee Khiang (Jalan Besar)(In Mandarin): Sir, in the Final Report of the Advisory Committee on TCS Chinese Drama and Variety Shows (ACCESS), 1996/98, it was pointed out, among other things, that TCS should not telecast programmes which are unsuitable for children, during the prime time. In the past, TCS used to schedule their programmes in such a way that certain types of programmes were telecast during certain time slots to cater for the different groups of viewers. However, as pointed out by the Advisory Committee, in recent years, there was a change in this kind of arrangement. I feel that the Singapore Broadcasting Authority should prepare a menu for TCS so that they would be guided as to when to telecast what kind of programme. Then, the Chinese Programme Advisory Committee (PAC) will not have to spend so much time to set out all this advice in its annual report. The Committee will then have more time to devote themselves on constructive suggestions and giving ideas on the production of better programmes, such as art programmes, documentaries, etc. to inculcate cultural values in our children and young people, for example, to encourage people to look after the old and the elderly.

    On the locally produced TV drama serials, I am glad to say that over the past few years, they have improved by leaps and bounds. But there is still room for improvement. On the whole, the programmes are good. There are not many big problems with the programmes. But, as pointed out in the final report of ACCESS, TCS should be careful not to introduce undesirable values in these serials, as these serials have considerable influence on our society at large.

    Looking at the TV programmes from another angle, when you are talking about the decline in viewership of our TV programmes, I think this is a bigger problem that we have to face. Because, basically, from the viewership, we can see

Column: 1281

the challenges facing TCS and SBA ahead. Comparing the viewership of our programmes with that of the imported ones, we can know how we fare.
12.45 pm

    Now, we have cable TV and wireless TV. Are there any differences in the programmes between the two? I think we have to consider this point.

    Thirdly, are the wireless TV Channel 5 and Channel 8 making profits or not?

    Fourthly, how are the programmes produced by us compared to those produced by Hong Kong and China which are now being telecast over cable TV?

    The decline of viewership for our local TV channels is not a totally unexpected phenomenon. I believe that in the years to come, viewership may continue to decline as cable TV gains popularity. I hope the Minister can take this opportunity to inform us of the future of cable TV and wireless TV. What kind of a role will TCS play in future?

    The next point is on digital TV. The advent of digital TV will also have an impact on television in Singapore. There will be some kind of revolutionary effect. I hope that the Minister can enlighten us on this new phase of development in television in Singapore.

    Mr Chew Heng Ching (East Coast): Sir, I rise to address some concerns specific to Singapore Cable Vision (SCV) or cable TV. Would the Minister be able to provide an update on the project to develop the infrastructure for Singapore to be a "wired city state"?

    One of the items on the agenda was to give every household access to cable TV, should they wish to subscribe to it. For HDB estates, the feasibility and the cost is reasonably efficient. But how does SCV handle landed estates where it could cost easily up to $3,000 to wire up an individual house? What if private estate residents refuse to pay this sum? What recourse does MITA or SCV have? Would the Minister please clarify?

Column: 1282



    Sir, further to my comment on the long-term role of TCS which I raised last Friday under an earlier amendment, I would like to seek clarifications from the Minister on what MITA see as the long-term role of SCV vis-a-vis TCS?

    Perhaps it is timely to review the definitions and the role of SCV versus TCS, in the light of the limited resources that we have. And I mentioned last Friday that we should try to avoid too much duplication of resources.

    Mr S. Iswaran (West Coast): Sir, first, I wish to declare my interest. I am a director at Singapore Technologies (Pte) Limited, which is one of the principal shareholders of Singapore Cable Vision (SCV).

    SCV is responsible for wiring up the entire island to ensure Singapore is cable ready by the end of next year, in time for the new millennium. I wish to take up, more specifically, the point just raised by my colleague, Mr Chew. I understand that progress in wiring up has been good. 80% of the HDB flats have been wired and I think about 40% of the private flats have also been similarly wired. The project has been extended to landed properties, and I understand the response from this segment of the population has been less than enthusiastic. I think the relatively high cost of getting wired up is the principal reason for this.

    If I may illustrate, Sir, for the typical HDB unit, the first TV point is free. For each subsequent point, the cost is $60-$70. This affordable rate is possible, partly because of a Government grant to SCV to wire up about 7,000 HDB blocks. For a typical private flat, the cost to the first TV point is $150 and $90 for each subsequent point. There is no Government subsidy, as far as I understand, but the operator is able to offer more competitive prices because of the density of these developments. But for private landed properties, the cost to the first point is at least $1,500 and, in some cases, as high as $3,000. This is largely because they have to foot the bill of the external wiring, to tap the main lines of Singapore Telecom and bring it to the household.

    Members of these households could reasonably ask the question whether the

Column: 1283

service or cable access they receive is worth paying 10 times as much or more as that paid by their counterparts in HDB or private flats. There are about 60,000-70,000 such households. I urge the Minister to consider extending a Government grant or some other form of measure to defray at least part of this cost which would otherwise have to be borne by these households. It would at least bring it to a level more comparable to that paid by private flats and HDB estates.

    One possible measure could be for Government, the household and SCV to bear this cost equally, for argument's sake, $500 each. I think this would amount to about $35 million investment for the Government as a one-off exercise. This would be a worthwhile investment in Singapore's IT infrastructure, as we all know that the cable network is not just a medium for TV programmes, it is part of Singapore One providing a high bandwidth network for access to the Internet and other multimedia applications. In time to come, a cable point is going to be as essential in the home as a telephone point, and we do not have this kind of differentiation when it comes to telephone points in the home. At least, the cost relativities are far less. It would therefore be a great pity, I think, if we do not seize this opportunity to ensure that all of Singapore is cable ready by the end of next year. I think, in my view, a Government financial stimulus would be a welcome catalyst in this respect.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang)(In Mandarin): Sir, Singapore is now developing into an IT hub. Our IT infrastructure and development are more advanced than our neighbouring countries. The strange thing is that countries such as Indonesia and Malaysia which are lagging behind us in IT development, are allowing their people to use the satellite dish freely to receive satellite TV telecast, while Singapore bans the use of such satellite dish.

    The Government is concerned that if people are allowed to tune in freely to undesirable programmes, such as pornography, from the satellite TV, this would have a grave adverse repercussion on our

Column: 1284

society. I agree with this stand. However, with the advance in technology, would the Minister consider the use of some kind of technology to block out such undesirable programmes from the satellite TV, so that they will not reach Singapore? Then the Government can allow people to install satellite dishes so that they can freely select and watch programmes from other parts of the world, particularly programmes on political commentaries.

    Mr Ong Ah Heng (Nee Soon Central)(In Mandarin): Sir, today, the younger generation of Singaporeans are receiving better education, and many of them are effectively bilingual. With the advancement in communications, the quality of life of our people has enhanced. Now, more and more Singaporeans are travelling overseas to broaden their visit and to motivate their pursuit for knowledge.

    At the moment, each of the four language streams has one daily newspaper. In addition, there is one afternoon English newspaper and two Chinese evening newspapers. As far as I know, many Singaporeans are hoping to have at least one more Chinese or English daily newspaper, so that they can have the option of an alternative newspaper to the existing one and only major language newspaper in Singapore.

    Sir, after 30 years of nation building, our people are more mature now. The younger generation of Singaporeans have received better education. They know how to distinguish between right and wrong. They are not easily instigated by others. So by giving them one more newspaper, their daily life could be further enriched. Under competition, I think the editorial contents and substance of the newspapers would be further improved and more quality reports will be provided for the benefit of the readers. To the advertisers, they will have an alternative choice to place their advertisement. It will also create more job opportunities for our mass communication students.

    In fact, the Government has already started what we call a "self-discipline" development in terms of education and culture. For example, the Ministry of

Column: 1285

Education is encouraging more independent schools to be set up so that they could have their own curriculum and methods of teaching, provided they comply with the guidelines issued by the Ministry of Education. Secondly, with cable TV and Internet getting more and more popular, it implies that MITA is allowing our people to be subjected to the impact of various views and schools of thoughts. Thirdly, we are allowing our cultural organisations more space for development, for example, busking. Under the necessary supervision, encouraging creativity and competition is a breakthrough. I hope that the Government would encourage any consortium which is interested to start a new major daily newspaper in Singapore.

    Mr Chew Heng Ching: Sir, I am sorry I did not catch your eye earlier. I am speaking on radio stations.

    Sir, in its efforts to further improve the radio services to better meet the needs of Singaporeans, the Radio Corporation of Singapore (RCS), following popular requests by MPs and the general public, introduced the arts radio station and the dialect news programmes over radio in recent months. I think these are good moves. It serves to benefit our arts loving Singaporeans and our senior citizens.

    Sir, the recent financial crisis developments in the region, the Indonesian crisis, the SilkAir MI 185 crash, the Thai baht crisis and so on, all show that there is a greater demand now for news coverage of international, regional and current events over radio. Singaporeans want to tune in to the latest on the news.

    Sir, I believe we have yet to have a station solely dedicated to providing up-to-date news. May I therefore ask the Minister what plans RCS has to set up more stations to cater to the needs of Singaporeans in general and the business community at large?

    Mr Seng Han Thong (Ang Mo Kio)(In Mandarin): Sir, Chinese news over Channel 8 enjoys one of the highest viewership, especially during this period of

Column: 1286

financial crisis and unrest in Indonesia. A lot of people are watching TV news on Channel 8. Two months ago, in January, TV news on Channel 8 itself became a focus of news because it failed to telecast the death of the well-known veteran comedian, Wang Sa. There was no mention at all over the TV news in the three days immediately after his death. A lot of people were talking about this omission. Personally, I believe that this omission was unintentional.

    This incident tells us that our society is still quite humane. Our veteran comedian died, and he is still being remembered by the people. They want more people to know about his death through the TV news.

    Sir, when we are going regional and international, the news on TCS should cover not only local news, but regional and international news as well, so that Singaporeans can cast their eyes not only on our society but on the whole world. This, I think, should be the policy of all media in Singapore. On top of that, we are a multi-racial society. One of our special features is the ability to seek concord while maintaining our differences. As such, the people of Singapore are concerned not only with common issues in our nation, our society and the region, but also what is happening in our own communities.

    As such, while covering the major events in the world and in Singapore, Channel 5, Channel 8 and Channel 12 share more or less the same contents. However, while covering news on the various communities, each has its own characteristics. At the same time, they do not exclude coverage on the other communities. This is to ensure that there is better understanding and familiarisation among the various communities.

    Take our Straits Times, Lianhe Zaobao, Beritan Harian, and Tamil Murasu, for example. Although their main focus is on Singapore, regional and international news, each has its own characteristics when covering events in their respective community. To understand the Chinese society, we should read Lianhe Zaobao.

Column: 1287

But Lianhe Zaobao also covers the news concerning the Malay and Indian communities as well. The Straits Times is targeted at the English educated and the bilingual readers, but it does not neglect the other communities.

    Singapore needs to have newspapers which have their own characteristics as well as common points. Likewise, Singapore needs to have different TV channels which have their own characteristics as well as common points.
1.00 pm

    Mr Peh Chin Hua (Jalan Besar)(In Mandarin): Sir, I am quite happy with the yardstick adopted by our Film Censorship Board. What we should cut we cut, what we should not cut, we keep. They will not affect the continuity of films. I have spent some time going to the movies, and I am quite happy with the PG movies. I feel MITA should reward the Board. As for the R(A) movies, I will try and find time to view these movies with my family so that I could give my feedback to the Minister.

    Our TV programmes are, on the whole, quite good. They are improved from time to time and over the past few years, there were winning praises from all quarters. My complaint is that there are many imported programmes and too few films from Singapore. Many foreign film producers are interested to come and invest in the film industry in Singapore. However, they feel that the procedure for various applications is too complicated. They have to go from one Ministry to another Ministry, and one department to another, to process their applications. A lot of time is wasted in these procedures. To film a programme with Singapore as a background, many permits have to be applied for, and many departments are involved. For example, if the film touches on life at a HDB estate, with schools, factories, riverside, etc., applications have to be made to the HDB, Town Council, URA, National Parks Board, Land Office, Ministry of the Environment, JTC, etc. Filming can commence only after permits have been granted by the various Ministries and departments. It is so cumbersome and troublesome. As a

Column: 1288

member of the Jalan Besar Town Council, I have also received letters from TCS for permission to film the activities of our Jalan Besar Town Council. Can we not simplify all these procedures? If we apply for a permit and must wait for approval from each and every agency before anything can be done, it will take a very long time and this is inconsistent with our pursuit for high efficiency in our society.

    I feel that so long as we have some control over the moral values depicted in the films, and our oriental values will not be adversely affected, then we should liberalise and simplify the procedures for permission to film in Singapore. We should provide a one-stop agency to handle all these applications. Producers need submit only one application and MITA will be able to coordinate and help them to get the approval so that filming can commence as soon as possible. This will be very useful in helping Singapore to become a film and movie hub in the Asia Pacific area. I hope that MITA will consider this to develop Singapore into a Hollywood of the East.

    Dr Ho Tat Kin (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, as Singapore moves towards high value-added industries, there should be a more concentrated effort to develop film as a core art form and a major drive to make Singapore a film industry centre in the region.

    With economic problems in the region, in South Korea, with recession in Hong Kong and Japan, the timing looks correct for this push. Unlike other high value-added industries, the film industry has low education entry barriers. A wide spectrum of jobs could be created for a wide range of age groups from the young to the old.

    Sir, ACCESS, the Advisory Committee on TCS Chinese Drama and Variety Show, in its February 1998 Report, also felt that TCS had an important role to play in the development of a full-fledged TV Centre and went on to say that TCS support was crucial for the development of an educated, mature film and TV profession in Singapore. ACCESS observes that the recruitment of creative talents continues to be a concern. The Committee hopes to

Column: 1289

see a long term solution to this issue. The Committee also recommends TCS to widen its search for instructors from England and the United States instead of focusing only on those from Hong Kong, Taiwan and China. The same report also recommends TCS to open some of the more general training workshops to non-TCS staff as well so that wider interests could be attracted and potential talents nurtured.

    Sir, may I ask what measures will MITA take to implement these recommendations?

    Sir, for the film industry to take off, there must also be alternatives to TCS productions. More production houses should be invited to Singapore. Just as my colleague, Mr Peh says, film companies feel that shooting movies in Singapore has many complications and they complain of difficulties in getting permission or permit for location shooting, lack of supporting infrastructure, post-production and animation facilities. Film companies feel that there are too many permits to apply from too many different Government and statutory bodies before they can start shooting.

    SBA is constantly caught between these two requirements, on the one hand, to maintain a certain level of public programming while, at the same time, understanding that the only way for TCS, TV12 and RCS to survive is to swim.

    What is the long-term position that we want? Our hope is for our national broadcasters eventually to have a position like that of the BBC in England. Today, the BBC operates in quite a free environment of competition, they still have 50% of the market share, with BBC1, BBC2 and the various stations on FM. I met John Birt recently and he told me that, with the advent of digital television, they have got to keep on moving. And from this year or next year, they are starting seven new TV stations, in addition to BBC1 and BBC2, three based on public funding and the other four commercially funded, including a 24-hour news channel and various other things.

    The challenge is not over. Digital TV, Internet TV, will confront us with new challenges and we must ensure that our local stations maintain their dominance in the English language, Chinese language, Malay language, Tamil, in radio and so on.

    In radio, despite fierce competition from abroad and from NTUC and SAFRA, RCS has managed to maintain dominance in every segment, and they have done well. TCS and TV12 will face more competition, particularly from SCV. What should they do? The strategy really is to concentrate on local programming, because that is the most difficult for international broadcasters to take away from them. It is not easy for a local radio station to compete with the BBC or CNN. But none of us would exclusively watch CNN or exclusively listen to BBC. Our day is not complete until we have also tuned in to our local radio station, local TV station, read our local newspapers. So we must ensure that our local newspapers, local television stations and local radio stations are able to maintain a certain position of

Column: 1308

dominance and credibility in our hearts and in our minds. If we say, only good stuff, unfortunately, a lot of good stuff is boring. After a long day's work, and Singaporeans work very hard, they go back home, they are not going to read War and Peace. They want entertainment. They want something simple and easy to digest. They sit back, be couch potatoes for a few minutes at the end of a hard day. And what we try to do is to build in some education, some social values into the programmes that we put out.

It is to send a signal. Even within a TV station, there are many players in competition with each other. From time to time, they get offside and the referee may have to wave a card. think we have got it about right now. The key points are summarised, encapsuled and put out in news times, it is on InTV, it is carried. audiences will understand this. Even Tamil Murasu has a very low circulation of less than 10,000 and finds it hard to break even, which was why they sold out to SPH.

If we allow overhead cabling in Singapore, this is not a problem, we can just hang it from pole to pole and get into your house. However, we require it to be dug under.     SCV is required by its licence to ensure that all estates are passed through by the end of 1999, which means that if you live in a semi-detached, or a terrace house or a bungalow, and you want it, you can have

Column: 1312

it. But you may have to pay for it, depending on where you live. If these are town houses and compact, then you will pay less. If you are living in a sprawling bungalow area, then you have to pay more. Even if you have to pay $2,000 for a house which is worth $10 million, I do not think it is disproportionate. It is not quite right to ask for a subsidy for the small number of Singaporeans who are already in the highest income bracket to be subsidised for having access to broadband. It is available to them. The infrastructure is already provided. But for the last bit to bring it into their homes, they must surely pay for that bit of it. It is like gas and electricity and water. The Government provides it to a particular point and you bring it into the house. I do not think it will be a problem because you cannot afford not to have it. Our objective in the end is to ensure that you have the telephone line, and with ADSL technology you can get a lot of bandwidth from it, and also a coaxial cable, and eventually there will probably be cellular wireless access into the house as well. Our whole telecommunication strategy is to ensure that within Singapore, bandwidth is not a problem at all. And for the kind of prices they are talking about for cabling, I do not think they are prohibitive.

    SCV, of course, can weight the payments differently. They can give you a free handphone and charge you a little more for the subscription.     On art policies, I would like to thank Mr Simon Tay for his stalwart and consistent support for the arts and artists. He made an important point that our objective is not just to trade in the arts which he inferred, when we said we want to be an arts hub. He said that we should foster local arts, and I agree with him entirely, in fact this has always been the objective of MITA and the NAC. It is very important that we foster the development of local arts because they express something very deep in the soul of the people. You ask yourself: what is the difference between a computer and a human being? Science, technology, solving calculus, memory banks, a computer can do any of these things, and do it better than we can. In the end, championship chess in the world will

Column: 1314

not be played between Deep Blue and Kasparov. It will be played between computers.

    So what is the difference between computers and human beings? Computers do not laugh and cry. They have no emotions. So the whole phenomenon of the art in human civilisation is not an add-on. It is not entertainment. It is something deep in the nature of man, in our biological and spiritual nature, which we do not fully understand. And to deny that aspect of us is a great danger. Then we will produce more Hector Yees. You may be very smart, but if you have no sense of where you came from, who your parents are, the schools you came from, the community from which you sprang, something is wrong. A computer programme, you press one button, the software gets transferred. You carry it from place to place, you buy it and you sell it. But human beings, like all animals, are not like that.

    A turtle may swim in the vast ocean but it never forgets the tiny stretch of beach from which it swam out. For birds and animals, it is encoded in the early memories. How much more for human beings! And the arts somehow reflect this. It is something from deep inside. And when we promote it, we are in fact affirming ourselves and our identity. Therefore, I agree with Dr Yaacob that we should make it a part of our education system, not in a stilted curricular way, prescribe it, you must have so much of it. No. But somehow to create an environment where people feel that they are incomplete without art. You may be very smart, but if you do not recognise this tune, or you cannot tell the difference between two paintings, there is something missing in you.

    If we can somehow create this environment in Singapore, then we would have succeeded. If we do not create this environment in Singapore, where the art carries no financial, moral or social value, then we will fail, and we will be a stunted tree which will not be able to take a storm. The word for it is pathos. How do you programme pathos into a computer and make it feel for people? You cannot. But a

Column: 1315

human being, even a Downs syndrome child, will have some of it in him or in her. This is the difference between a human life and a smart computer, and the reason why the arts are not an add-on, not a luxury, but something which is very important. And Government takes it as something which is very important.

    I think the private sector does as well because every time we have fund raising for a violinist or for a good cause, people turn up and try their best to be helpful. And interestingly, it is in times of crisis that real creative work is done, not in times of prosperity. In times of prosperity, you may have beautiful paintings and beautiful studios and so on. But deep feelings are the result of people caught with having to make tough choices, and re-examining the conditions of their existence and then coming up with new creative alternatives, and that is when artistic developments take place. So I see this financial crisis as being two-edged for the arts. It is not completely a bad thing. The crisis will itself provoke new thinking and deepen our sense of being Singaporean.

    The advantage of having our debate on bond-breaking here is that, at the end of it, our thoughts crystallise, the line between right and wrong is more clearly demarcated, our position is consolidated. Across the whole front now, because of the financial and economic crisis in the region, new positions will be established. This will make us stronger. It will better defend us as Singaporeans. For this, our musicians, our poets, our prose writers, our painters, our calligraphers, will make their contributions.

manager coming to see me to get my help for a hot-air balloon to be put up over Singapore for a dramatic scene between Andy Lau and Li Nanxing, a final moment before some cataclysm occurred, and he wanted Singapore as a backdrop. we need very much to teach that they are Chinese, Indians, Malays or Muslims, or Buddhists - these things are powerfully transmitted through families and through religions - but that we are Singaporeans in good times and in bad, that is much harder. This year, over 1,500 students turned up, and they put up an exhibition which will now be compiled into a book.     There are many other efforts being made by various groups. I think they should be encouraged. Force 136, they worked with TCS to create a series called

Column: 1319

the Price of Peace, and this was very well received, and in the process of enjoying a very good TV serial, young Singaporeans learnt about a very important part of their past, when local people, despite the fact that they were a colonised people, fought, sacrificed their lives, in order to keep the land free.

    Time is running out. If I can summarise, the character of a people is shaped more by adversity than by prosperity. A long boom has ended. We are going through a period of crisis. It can be a very bad crisis. It can be a relatively minor crisis for us. But there is no doubt that across the region, it is a very major crisis. And because of this crisis, the character of Asia will change. The fundamental attitudes towards the market, towards America, towards China, towards Japan, towards religion, will change, as a result of this crisis. Our national character was very much forged as a result of the British colonial experience, of the Second World War, of the fight against the Communists, of our traumatic years in Malaysia, and of our need to survive when we became independent. In the same way, this crisis will reshape young minds, and young people who thought that the boom will never end, are suddenly confronted with the harsh reality of living in a tumultuous world, and discovering what their own strengths and weaknesses are. So if we put our minds to it, all of us, as teachers, as parents, as MPs, as entrepreneurs, as workers, as unionists, we can turn this crisis into a strengthening experience, once out of it, we will emerge much stronger as a people. In a crisis like this, either we go through it stronger or we go through it weakened. No one will go through it intact, everyone of us. No one is spared. But if we do it right, if the people and the Government work together, then I have no doubt that across all fields, we will emerge stronger.
